ygData.subject: Re: How to load (and use) a previously saved genome
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi David, thanks for the detailed explanation. I ve found the bug; shame on me, the input data wasn t exactly the same (that s the problem with hard coded

Hi David,

thanks for the detailed explanation. I've found the bug; shame o=
n me, the input data wasn't exactly the same (that's the problem with hard =
coded parameters :)).

However, it's great that this functionality is now d=
escribed in such detail. This could be a first step towards a tutorial / wi=
ki or whatever.

Cheers,
Daniel

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "ddambroeplex=
" <ddambro84@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Daniel,
> 
> I was just recently informed a=
bout the no hidden nodes bug and I was going to release an updated version,=
 but then the issue of the optimization was brought up, so I decided to wai=
t until I decided what to do with that before I released anything.  I apolo=
gize for that.
> 
> As for getting different results when reloading genomes=
, the most common reason for this error have been conflicting or missing pa=
rams.txt files, as Colin suggested.  The only other situations I've run int=
o have been accidentally using different substrates and recently when someo=
ne created their visualizer project the references to SharpNeatLib got mess=
ed up.  That last one seemed like a special case, but you can test for it b=
y using this code outline to load and test a genome in your main class.  Yo=
u can also use MessageBox.show() in your visualization project with this co=
de to see if that produces the correct fitness value.
> 
> NeatGenome testG=
enome;		
> try
> {
> 	XmlDocument XML =3D new XmlDocument();
> 	XML.Load(te=
stGenomeFilename);
> 	testGenome =3D XmlNeatGenomeReaderStatic.Read(XML);
>=
 }
> catch (Exception e)
> {
> 	System.Console.WriteLine("Problem loading g=
enome: \n" + e.Message);
> 	System.Environment.Exit(1);
> }
> YourNetworkEv=
aluator eval =3D new YourNetworkEvaluator();
> double fitness =3D eval.netw=
orkEvaluate(testGenome.Decode());
> System.Console.WriteLine("Fitness:  " +=
 fitness);
> 
> Failing that, your method #3 was correct.  The process for =
loading a genome is:
> 
> 1. Setup experimental parameters.
> 2. Load the X=
ML into a genome.
> 3. Decode the genome into a CPPN (as an INetwork)
> 4. =
Use your Substrate to query the CPPN, producing a NeatGenome or INetwork th=
at will be used in the domain.
> 
> So that seems OK.  You can try dumping =
the INetworks produced by the substrate (i.e. the actual ANNs being evaluat=
ed) of the best genomes to XML and compare those to the networks you get fr=
om loading the genomes back in during visualization and putting them throug=
h the substrate.  If they are the same, perhaps some of the domain paramete=
rs are different?  If they are different, check that the substrates and rel=
ated parameters are the same (using YourNetworkEvalutor.substrate can help =
with this issue).
> 
> Let me know how things go,
> David D'Ambrosio
> 
> -=
-- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel" <daniel_kuppitz@> wrote:
> >
> > No, I=
 use the same params.txt in each project. But what I found out now is that =
I've mixed up the constructor parameters; instead of passing the 9 as the o=
utput neuron parameter I passed it as the hidden neuron parameter. After ch=
anging that I got one OutOfMemoryException after another. There's a bug in =
Substrate.cs in line 133:
> > 
> > for (uint outputs =3D 0; outputs < outpu=
tCount; output++, coordinates[2] +=3D outputDelta)
> > 
> > should be
> > 
=
> > for (uint outputs =3D 0; outputs < outputCount; outputs++, coordinates[=
2] +=3D outputDelta)
> > 
> > I'm quite sure that I never touched this line=
 of code. Unfortunately my initial problem is back - the visualizer produce=
s different outputs. I surely overlook something, I have just no idea what =
it is.
> > 
> > Cheers,
> > Daniel
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Co=
lin Green <colin.green1@> wrote:
> > >
> > > 2009/11/29 Daniel <daniel_kupp=
itz@>
> > > >
> > > > The confusion deepens. I've changed the activation fu=
nction to BipolarsSigmoid and guess what: Same input results in the same
> =
> > > output now.
> > > > I really don't understand it, but it's great to h=
ave a visualizer now :)
> > > 
> > > 
> > > I wonder if the wrong parameter=
 or params.txt file is being read when
> > > you're evolving the networks? =
So they might have been using
> > > BipolarSigmoid all along?
> > >
> >
>

=
